name: 3-thiaheptane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.

name: 3-thiaheptane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit for 3-thiaheptane can be considered as butane which has a melting point of -138.3 degrees Celsius. Each additional methylene group (CH2) in the alkane series typically increases the melting point by about 20 degrees Celsius. In 3-thiaheptane, there are two additional methylene groups added to butane, which would contribute an increase of 40 degrees Celsius. The sulfur atom (thia group) replacing a methylene group is larger and more polarizable than carbon, which generally increases the melting point through stronger van der Waals forces. Assuming the sulfur contributes a similar increase as a methylene group, the total increase would be around 40 degrees Celsius from the base butane value.
